I'm a med student, I used to sleep 6 hours, a day a year ago and was sleeping 6 hours a day for 3-4 years and was fine with it. I used to brag about it, that see I sleep very little, then one of my teachers in my med school showed a graph of sleep vs life expectancy. that graph shows that people who sleep less than 7.5 hours have less life expectancy but vice versa isn't true, that means people who sleep more than 8-9 hours too had less life expectancy. The graph was at a peak at 7.5-8 hours, my teacher said if you sleep less than 7.5 hours try sleeping 7.5 to 8 hours for a week it will do wonders for you. I tried and here I'm writing my experience, so my brain functioning increased my focus increased dramatically and I was able to study for a longer period with full concentration and from the last 1years, I'm sleeping 8 hours a day. I realised that when I was sleeping less I was far less productive than I'm right now. if I would have started sleeping this way during high school, I would have gotten much better med school than the one I'm right now....
Peace ✌️

Tired? We all know the feeling. Irritable, groggy and exceptionally lazy. Chances are, you didn’t sleep enough last night. Or the past few nights, but what exactly is enough sleep and more importantly, can you ever catch up on it? While the very function of sleep is still debated by scientists, we do know that it’s necessary to function efficiently and productively.

2 – After all, we spend 24 years of our lifetime sleeping, it had better be important. Researchers have tested how much is required each night by assigning groups of people to 4, 6 and 8 hours of sleep over extended periods of time. After 14 days, those with 8 hours of sleep exhibited few attention lapses or cognitive issues. However, those with 6 or 4 hours of sleep showed a steady decline.

3 – In fact, after only two weeks, the 6-hour group showed a similar reaction to a person with the blood alcohol concentration of 0.1%, which is considered legally drunk. The 4 hour sleepers suffered even more, occasionally falling asleep during their cognitive tests. In both groups, brain function decreased day by day, almost linearly with no sign of levelling off. Scientists have dubbed this cumulative effect as Sleep Debt.

4 – So can we recover from it? After a night or two of little sleep, studies show that the body and brain can fully recover with a few nights of good sleep. However, with long term sleep deprivation on the scale of weeks to months, the recovery of cognitive function is much slower, requiring many more nights of quality sleep. On the time scale of months to years, it’s unknown whether brain function can be fully repaired or if it causes permanent damage.

5 – Paradoxically, with chronic sleep deprivation, your sleepiness, or how tired you feel does eventually level off, meaning that you become less and less aware of your objective impairment over time. So how long should you sleep? Most studies tend to show that 7 to 8 hours is the average ideal for humans. Apart from the cognitive issues, individuals who consistently sleep less than 7 hours a night have an increased risk of heart disease, obesity and diabetes.

6 – Not to mention, a 12% higher risk of death. On the flipside, studies have shown that while sleeping more than 8 hours does not impair brain function, it also carries an increased risk of heart disease, obesity and diabetes and a 30% increased risk of mortality. So, too much sleep may also be a bad thing. But variation most certainly exists and our genetics play a large role.

7 – In fact, individuals genuinely unaffected by only 6 hours of sleep were found to have a mutation of a specific gene. When scientists genetically engineered mice to express this gene, they were able to stay awake for an extra 1.2 hours than normal mice. It turns out, these short sleepers have more biologically intense sleep sessions than the average person.

8 – Ultimately, while it’s important to know the ideal average of 7-8 hours exists, let your body and brain help you figure out its own needs. After all, no one shoe size fits all. If you want to know how to get better quality sleep each night in order to conquer the hurdles of sleep deprivation, we have some tips and research for you over on ASAP Thought. You can find the link in the description below to that video.

Audible is the leading provider of audiobooks with over 150,000 downloadable titles across all types of literature. We recommend the ‘A Song of Ice and Fire’ series which the Game of Thrones TV show is based off of. It’s kept us up through the night and caused a lot of lost sleep.

Tired? We all know the feeling. Irritable, groggy and exceptionally lazy. Chances are, you didn’t sleep enough last night. Or the past few nights, but what exactly is enough sleep and more importantly, can you ever catch up on it? While the very function of sleep is still debated by scientists, we do know that it’s necessary to function efficiently and productively.

2 – After all, we spend 24 years of our lifetime sleeping, it had better be important. Researchers have tested how much is required each night by assigning groups of people to 4, 6 and 8 hours of sleep over extended periods of time. After 14 days, those with 8 hours of sleep exhibited few attention lapses or cognitive issues. However, those with 6 or 4 hours of sleep showed a steady decline.

3 – In fact, after only two weeks, the 6-hour group showed a similar reaction to a person with the blood alcohol concentration of 0.1%, which is considered legally drunk. The 4 hour sleepers suffered even more, occasionally falling asleep during their cognitive tests. In both groups, brain function decreased day by day, almost linearly with no sign of levelling off. Scientists have dubbed this cumulative effect as Sleep Debt.

4 – So can we recover from it? After a night or two of little sleep, studies show that the body and brain can fully recover with a few nights of good sleep. However, with long term sleep deprivation on the scale of weeks to months, the recovery of cognitive function is much slower, requiring many more nights of quality sleep. On the time scale of months to years, it’s unknown whether brain function can be fully repaired or if it causes permanent damage.

5 – Paradoxically, with chronic sleep deprivation, your sleepiness, or how tired you feel does eventually level off, meaning that you become less and less aware of your objective impairment over time. So how long should you sleep? Most studies tend to show that 7 to 8 hours is the average ideal for humans. Apart from the cognitive issues, individuals who consistently sleep less than 7 hours a night have an increased risk of heart disease, obesity and diabetes.

6 – Not to mention, a 12% higher risk of death. On the flipside, studies have shown that while sleeping more than 8 hours does not impair brain function, it also carries an increased risk of heart disease, obesity and diabetes and a 30% increased risk of mortality. So, too much sleep may also be a bad thing. But variation most certainly exists and our genetics play a large role.

7 – In fact, individuals genuinely unaffected by only 6 hours of sleep were found to have a mutation of a specific gene. When scientists genetically engineered mice to express this gene, they were able to stay awake for an extra 1.2 hours than normal mice. It turns out, these short sleepers have more biologically intense sleep sessions than the average person.

8 – Ultimately, while it’s important to know the ideal average of 7-8 hours exists, let your body and brain help you figure out its own needs. After all, no one shoe size fits all. If you want to know how to get better quality sleep each night in order to conquer the hurdles of sleep deprivation, we have some tips and research for you over on ASAP Thought. You can find the link in the description below to that video.

Actually.. total time you spend sleeping is not that important. What's important for your mental recovery is how many REM phases you have per day. Normally you have a healthy amount of REM phases (4-6. Most people have 6) in your 7-8 hours of sleep. However, the amount of sleep itself doesnt need to be high. There are sleep rhythms that maximize the REM phases while minimizing the time wasted sleeping. You can have as little as 2 hours of sleep a day and still be healthy. At least there is no evidence to assume it is unhealthy. The only read problem with that is that monophasic sleep fits in our "unnatural" day to day life, while polyphasic sleep is hard to integrate into your work schedule.

However.. just imagine how much longer your life could be if you didnt waste as much time sleeping. In the best case scenario you could save like 6 hours a day. Six freaking hours. Every day. That's over 90 (!) more days.. PER YEAR.

I think it's dumb. Science backs up the proof of us needing 8+ hours of sleep but how am I supposed to do that? School prohibits it. I go to school for 8 hours starting at 6:30am going until 2:30pm then I go home and do about 3+ hours depending on if I have a project or a test or something to study for. Then I need to get at least 2 hours to myself to rejuvenate and calm my stress levels from the 11+ hours of learning/busywork/homework that I've done. By now it's about 6:30pm about time to start cooking dinner. Let's say it takes an hour to cook and you eat at 7:30. It takes another 30mins to an hour to clean up so now it's 8:30. Then you have to spend some time with your family and tell them about your day and school and all of that crap. Now it's 9. You go upstairs get ready for bed which includes changing to bed time clothes, washing your face and applying creams and removing makeup, brushing your teeth, and anything else that's in your nightly routine. Now it's ten. Ten is about the time you head into bed and with today's society you spend about an hour on your phone/laptop again trying to calm your stress levels from the long day. Now you exhausted and decide to read a good book until you finally pass out at 12. Then you have to be awake again at 5am to get ready in time to catch your bus. This gives you a grand total of 5 hours of sleep. Let's assume you're doing this 6-12th grades. (That's about how my schedule had been going) now that's 7 years of constant sleep deprivation. So please tell me that our school systems are not messed up and that we shouldn't be sleep deprived.

These studies are flawed... be careful when you make conclusions from such; For example, in the 3 group study, the subjects are inherently miss-assigned to groups, and the results invalid, if they are randomly assigned and thus at odds with the natural sleep needs of the subjects... compounded by the fact the population of sleepers (everyone) is not evenly distributed in relation to sleep needs, with those needing the least sleep in the genetic/populational minority. Another example is the health study... Two groups were mentioned, less than 7 and more than 8... This is basically just a populational cross section and has nothing to do with sleep... thus irrelevant to the point and the video... Watch out for erroneous conclusions, we still have much to learn. These kinds of videos are not only wrong but can be mentally damaging as well.

I know many people who have been bent out of shape for months based on the 7-8 hour bullshit rule.  Where ever this idea came from is beyond me but let me tell you this....every human is different.  Some of us need 8 hours, some 10, some only 4.  And no, there is none of this bullshit where you "think" you are getting enough sleep.  If you feel refreshed and are able to function during the day, then you are getting enough sleep.  I know many people who get 5 hours a day and are very quick witted and intelligent people.  I also know people who get 8+ and seem completely out of it every time you talk to them.

Videos or articles that show the negative effects of less than 8 hours of sleep only do one thing.....worry those who only get 5-6 hours but are perfectly fine.  These people start to worry that they are not getting enough sleep, get what is called sleep anxiety, which is basically the fear of not being able to sleep, and that actually creates more problems for them.  I know people (including myself) who were perfectly fine at 5 hours of sleep but then heard the "8 hours" myth and then couldn't sleep at all because every night they became so worried about lack of sleep.

Oh, and that "permanent damage" line is bs.  My dad has said he has only slept 6 hours a night since he was 15 and he is 59 now and still has all his cognitive functions and seems to not have suffered at all.  If there is any damage it is so miniscule you would never realize it.  However, because you spread this crap you are going to give people who were otherwise fine in life a reason to fret over sleep.

I used to have horrible sleep anxiety because I bought into all the lack of sleep myths and eventually came to realize they are just that; myths...legends....fairy tales.  Yes, some nights I can't sleep a wink and yes, the next day is rough but eventually I do sleep and guess what....the next day I am back to my normal self.  We need to start giving our unconscious mind and our bodies more credit.  If you don't sleep more than likely it's because your body didn't feel the need to or felt another issue was of greater importance.  Yes, there are causes for insomnia that cause us to lack in sleep, but eventually our bodies correct the issue.  Unless you have some fatal disease that maybe 10 people have had throughout human history you will eventually fall asleep.  Our bodies act depending on what they perceive as most important.  If you are hungry all you want to do is eat, if your are thirsty all you want is water, and if you are completely deprived of sleep your body will shut down until it has adequate rest. 

So people, if you are not getting 8 hours, don't fret.  If you wake up after 6, 5, or even 4 hours and feel refreshed, don't question it.  Odds are your body is trying to say "hey, were good now, lets get the day started."  Once you need to sleep, your body will let you know.  Don't listen to any other crap that says otherwise.

There is a period of time right before my you-know-what starts, where it is like I've been hit by a truck. Not only will I sleep ten or eleven hours that night, but I feel the need to crash several hours during the following day as well. I'm so tired I can barely move. I will still also sleep soundly the following night, although I go back to my average...more or less.

If I have to work the day this is in effect, it's a nightmare. My body is screaming for sleep and I can't let it. Somehow or other, I always muddle through, though. I used to wonder if I was normal for this....then eventually found out that many other women had something similar happen to them.

Once or twice a year, it will happen again shortly after my period starts, right at its heaviest and right when I'm physically at my most miserable. I'm glad it doesn't happen every month. Just those rare occurrences when I'm also suffering a LOT of cramping to go along with it.

If you are having trouble with getting to sleep at night and then waking up early in the morning try this; First of all change your eating patterns. Eat more fruits and veggies and less junk food like potato chips and soda. That should alone get you a better sleep because your body has enough vitamins and nutrients to function properly which includes shutting down and having enough energy to wake up in the morning. You could also try allowing your body to shut down 1-2 HOURS before your ideal sleeping time. You can figure that out by what time you want to wake up in the morning. Try to match that out so that you are getting at least eight solid hours of sleep for example if you want to wake up at 7am start winding down for bed at 9pm aiming to be in bed and asleep by 11pm. Some winding down activities you may want to try are; Having a nice hot bath or shower, staying away from electronic devices such as a cell phone or television and instead read a book or do art or knit. You could also do other activities such as yoga or meditation. Try to resist eating anything heavy in the hour before you plan to be in bed but do make sure you have been well fed before you go to sleep because this could result in needing to wake up in the night and interrupting your sleep cycle. Also make sure you have gone to the toilet before you go to bed. It may not cause you to wet the bed but it might also result in waking in the night and also interrupting your sleeping cycle. try to resist doing anything that would cause stress or unease because this can lead to feeling unrested when it is time to wake up. Try to reduce the amount of alcohol or drugs that you consume. You may even want to stop it all together. Especially if you frequently smoke or use tobacco. Believe it or not but STOP DRINKING MORNING COFFEE! It is NOT good for you! It is absolutely terrible for your body to rely on a substance to keep you going throughout the day especially if it's a caffeinated one! You don't need it and your screwing up your whole system by telling yourself that you do. You don't need caffeine! Caffeine may be part of what is causing your sleeping issues! For those who are afraid of the dark (myself included) even though it may be scary DON'T leave the light on at night! This may be what is causing your sleeping problems. Your body needs a good sleep and that may not be achievable if you are constantly in the light. Last but not least try taking Melatonin. For those who have never heard of it Melatonin in a substance in your body that helps shut the body down and prepare it for sleep and wake. Many people who have sleeping issues (including myself) have those issues because they have a lack of melatonin in their body so the easy fix to that is purchasing some from your local drugstore and taking it about a half an hour before you wish to sleep. If you have tried all of these things and nothing has worked consult a doctor. You may need therapy to solve whatever is preventing you from getting the amount of sleep that you need. Also you may be low on iron which can lead to serious issues so take care of your body and ensure you're letting your body get what it needs to stay healthy. Hope this was helpful to somebody! :)

One point to consider about the sleep statistics presented here: It says sleeping more than 8 hours may put you at risk for multiple health issues. A wider survey of studies shows this is probably putting the cart in front of the horse. It is more likely that you already have those health issues or are in the developing stages of the disease and you are sleeping more because your body is trying to heal itself. Your body does almost all of its healing and growth work while you are asleep. That's why if you're seriously injured or sick, your body wants to sleep all the time. So if you're sleeping more than 8 hours and are frequently fatigued but aren't sick (yet), the culprit is probably a combination of overworking, chronic stress, and malnutrition - all of which are known causes of the same diseases mentioned in the video above.

It's really simple. Follow the day cycle. An hour or so after it becomes dark, go to sleep. You will rise with the sun. Ofc, the problem is in this day and age, it's very non practical to do so.

I struggle with sleep and its all down to my lifestyle to be honest, but when I do focus on things I can get into a good quality pattern of sleep.

For me the most important thing is to get used to sleeping in the dark, and by dark I mean pitch black. No little red "standby" lights, no street lights (black out blinds) etc. Reduce sound as much as possible too.. don't have a computer sitting idle in your room with that buzzing fan noise or external HDDs spinning up etc. Kill sound as much as possible.. get ear plugs to drown out noisy neighbors or house mates.

Also important is stop eating at least 3-4 hours before you intend to sleep. I also stop drinking anything at the same time, but I always leave a glass of water beside the bed in case I wake up thirsty.

A good way to help yourself drift off is to take a bath before u intend to sleep. Shower doesn't really do the trick. Basically when you get out of the bath and dry off, go right to bed and you'll drift off much easier. Works for kids too :-)

Try to keep electronics in your room switched off... we all love to watch TV in bed but TV stimulates the brain and we've all been there... absolutely determined to sleep but we put on TV and something good is on so we say.... OK OK I'll just watch this... and end up cutting an hour or more off of our sleep.

Reading is also a killer to sleep, we think it helps us drift off but really it also stimulates the mind, and nowadays we use e-readers that have back lights putting out light closer to the blue-end of the spectrum, which is the light that actually signals to our brain that it is day time. 

Another thing I find absolutely essential is exercise.. at least do some walking. I find it helps with the quality of sleep :-) Caffeine doesn't stop me from sleeping but it definitely affects the quality of my sleep. 

As for waking up in the morning.. this is one drawback of sleeping in complete darkness.. even after 8 hours u can feel crappy but the trick is to expose yourself to blue light. If its morning and bright just open the curtains and blinds, but you can also buy little blue-light lamps that are made for the purpose of helping you to wake up. I keep one in the bathroom for when I'm shaving, brushing teeth etc. a few minutes and I'm all good :-)

But ye, more often than not I fall off my pattern due to work complications and other parts of my lifestyle but when I can hold that pattern for a while I do feel great and I sleep very well :-)

I would love to see a second take on this with some commentary on polyphasic sleep cycles. I've only slept four hours a night since I was a toddler. I was diagnosed with ADHD (although I never medicated), and so my mother thought this was an aspect of the hyperactivity. Now, at 35, I have little problem with focus, or have few symptoms associated with adult ADHD, but still sleep 4 hours a night, usually from 11:30 PM to 3:30 AM. I take one nap at 12:30 the following afternoon, and will sometimes increase this to 90 minutes depending on the remainder of my day's activities. This is similar to the "Everyman Schedule" but I tend to require less than the three naps this schedule recommends. I don't suffer from any fatigue, or have any health concerns.

I'm a full time web developer working in an extremely break-neck industry for a large team. With lots of 12 hour days, I find my sleep cycle naturally allows me to do the things I enjoy while keeping up with an extremely demanding work schedule. I can't be troubled to do the math, but I believe this gives you nearly two months of extra time throughout the year.

PLEASE HUMOR ME FOR A MINUTE OF YOUR TIME.
It is not the burden of those who DO NOT believe in a God's existence to prove he DOES NOT EXIST.
The intellectual responsibility of proving a positive is on the individual attempting to prove THAT positive. In this case, that there is a God or a higher power.
Proving a negative is NEVER the responsibility of the one that holds that belief.
This is a fundamental tenant of any entry level college course in Logic.
For example, suppose you are a doctor and you believe there is a new more terrifying form of HEPATITIS. Let's call it Hepatitis Z.
You have seen the signs and symptoms and the significant differences in this form of Hepatitis in many many recent patients of yours confined to a certain geographical area. You see the disease affecting ONLY the LIVER. Another doctor has seen the same signs and symptoms in several of his/her patients in this same confined geographical area. However, he doesn't believe it's a different form of HEPATITIS. This doctor believes it's a different strain of HEPATITIS C but it is affecting multiple organ systems NOT JUST THE LIVER.
IN THIS HYPOTHETICAL It is the doctor who is attempting to prove the POSITIVE, as in this case, of a totally new disease. In this hypothetical- HEPATITIS Z.

I have DSPS (Delayed Sleep Pattern Syndrome), a condition where my 'most profitable' hours of sleep (or in other words, my biological clock) prefers sleep at "abnormal hours". My sleepiness kicks in around 5am and lasts untill 1pm. Since my life (school, work, ...) isn't adjusted to this, I usually get less sleep than some other people. Because of this I get major headaches (migraines) when I get too little sleep, but also have more difficulty doing simple things (such as building phrases or normal grammar), and become easily physically tired aswell. Sleep is important, I know this much, and I advise everyone to try and get enough of it, even if it's just to avoid a higher chance of getting alzheimers' disease when you're old. (I was diagnosed with DSPS by a doctor, if you have sleeping issues, I hope you do the same, they can help you.)

While its an nice overview of the issue of sleep, it still lacks the information about the biological rhythms of humans. There are many studies showing the diversity and individuality of the sleeping cycles that are good for different individuals. So, while it might be true that for a lot of people (at some point in their lives) it is best to sleep around 8 hours/night, you could have emphasized a little more that it is a personal thing that depends on many factors such as age, gender your genetics and so on.

A professor who devoted his life on this (Dr Till Roenneberg) has also coined a term "Social Jet-Lag" ,which is a very Interesting phenomena (and a serious problem) caused by disregard of the diversity of our inner clocks, avoidance of natural light and the unhealthy social time pressure. It is based on an idea that all of us have different biological inner clocks (Therefore different chronotypes), however the whole society operates on the basis of one and the same "social clock" which makes some people suffer and others prosper.

I feel that "Social jet-lag" and "Late and Early chronotypes" would be an Interesting topic for you to discuss in one of your videos!

It's a pretty bad video.  Because, as you can see from the comments, people watch it and take away that 7-8 hours per night is the law.  While it's not even the rule.  It's just the average.  Which means that some need more, some need less.  The (vast?) majority needs between 7 and 8.  Actually, I've read that we usually sleep in 1 1/2 hour phases, so 7 1/2 would be the sweet spot.  But I can't cite any source for that, even though it would flow logically from what we do know about sleep phases.

Yes, you do speak about variation at the end.  For about 30 seconds.  While not mentioning any variation for the first 2 minutes.  Even the study you lead off with gets no mention of variation, just the opposite, "However, those with 6 or 4 hours of sleep showed a steady decline".  No exceptions, no variation, no "on average".

Ive been on this thing called the "everyman sleep cycle". Basically, i only sleep 4 hours a night, that is: 2am - 5am core sleep, and then 3 20-minute naps throughout the day: one at 12 pm, 5 pm, and 10 pm. This allows me to stay awake for a whooping 20 hours a day WITHOUT feeling tired or restless. The naps automatically put me into REM sleep (as the video said), and then the 3 hours core sleep is REM sleep also. You only need 4 hours of REM sleep to be fully recovered, and when you finish your REM sleep, you are actually getting tired WHILE you sleep, hence why you wake up sometimes and youre still tired after like a 10 hr sleep. If i sleep 8 hours out of a 24 hour day, then Ive slept 1/3 of the day. if i continue that routine throughout my life, then when Im 60, I will only have been awake for 40 years (60*1/3= 40). I dont want to do this. Life is short as it is. I recommend the everyman sleep cycle (polyphasic sleep cycle) to everyone who can manage it. This is it what i call living.

...That explains a lot! I had an awfull insomnia a few years ago when I was little for about 2 years, where I didn't sleep for days and then I could only sleep like 1 hour and that was it. After that I started to sleep more and more, until I not only slept every night, I also slept for hours! that was a lot for me at the time. But after a few years I started sleeping a lot more, every night I needed more than 12 hours of sleep or it wasn't enough for me. Now I just can sleep whatever I want and I would be ok, from 30 minutes to 18 hours, I don't feel the need to stay awake or sleep. Is convinient because I can stay awake for long periods and finish work if is needed, and I can also just sleep all weekend if I want to compensate. But I try to sleep at least 10 hours a day normally, just in case that some day I find myself unable to sleep again.

As a side note, if you find yourself groggy when you feel you need to take a nap, drink a bit of caffeine before you take said nap. When you wake up, the caffeine will kick in and give you a bit of a boost instead of leaving you feeling normally tired to groggy like you usually do after a nap.

The 7-8 hours of sleep is true for adults. However, when in other age groups, more hours are most likely needed.

- 0-1 years old : 13-14 hours of sleep per day.
- 1-3 uears old : 10-12 hours of sleep per day
- 3-6 years old: 9-10 hours of sleep per day
- 6-12 years old: 7-8 hous of sleep per day
- 12 - 16/17 (when in puberty) : 8-9 hours of sleep per day, and you are more likely to get in a rythem of sleeping more during the day/feeling more sleepy during the day and feel fully awake at evening/nightime. It shifts for about 2-3 hours ahead of normal bedtime (youll feel sleepy at arround 1-2 o'clock and sleep to 10-12 in the morning when given the chance). This has to do with cognitive changes in the brain and natural selection where in the primitive age, fit young man could protect the family at night time.
17- 60 years old: 7-8 hours of sleep, and may go a bit up in mid-life crisis/menopause.
60 + years old : 8-9 hours of sleep, and more is needed when you grow progressivly older. .

Your circadian (sleep/wake) cycle also controls 1/3 of your epigenetic function and every one of your hormones. Sleeping enough is important, but sleeping/waking at the same time is even more important. Disruptions in cortisol, insulin, gastrin, melatonin, adrenaline, etc = irritability, digestive problems, blood sugar imbalance, cognitive decline, and misery. That's why some people feel terrible after taking naps. Throws off the daily cortisol cycle, which throws everything else out of whack.
